class.title: Cooperative Ed. - Accounting
class.description: Accounting Work Study classes are for students who plan to complete an accounting associate degree. Students must be employed in an accounting-related position. Students who have completed ACNT 1380 should enroll in ACNT 2380. (Students employed in non-accounting positions should enroll in ACNT 1366 or ACNT 2366.) Course content is provided online; coop visits to work site are required. After enrolling, enter http://ecampus.dcccd.edu and log in using your seven- digit student ID number as both the username and password. Contact bKnickel@dcccd.edu for information.

class.title: Web Site Design
class.description: ARTC 2375-2426 will focus on working with clients creating Web sites and other graphics with an online orientation. Requires access to Internet using a current browser (not AOL), e-mail and software for crafting Web sites and graphics for your operating system. class.title: Problems in Contemporary Art
class.description: Major art movements of the early 20th century: Fauvism, Cubism, DADA, deStijl and Surrealism. Students will learn how these art movements reflect individual and collective attitudes toward artmaking as well as mirror political events in Europe before 1950.
class.alt-description: Major Art Major art movements of the early 20th century: Fauvism, Cubism, DADA, deStijl and Surrealism. Students will learn how these art movements reflect individual and collective attitudes toward artmaking as well as mirror political events in Europe before 1950.

class.title: Problems in Contemp. Art II
class.description: Major art movements of the mid-late 20th century. Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Pop, Happenings and Performance, Land/Environmental Art, Pluralism/Globalism. Students will learn how the center of the art world moves from Paris to New York and stays there until the end of the 20th century.
class.alt-description: Major art movements of the mid-late 20th century. Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Pop, Happenings and Performance, Land/Environmental Art, Pluralism/Globalism. Students will learn how the center of the art world moves from Paris to New York and stays there until the end of the 20th Century.

It is online and requires access to the Internet and e-mail along with Microsoft Office 2003, Office XP (Office 2002) or Office 2000 software, including Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Access. The orientation will be given online. For more information, call 972-860-4746 or e-mail bhcCIT@dcccd.edu or enter the Dallas TeleCollege web site at http://telecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Game Prog 1 - C#
class.description: COSC 1430-2501 is an introductory course to C# and an intensive introduction to the concepts of 2d game programming, including 2d animation, blitting, sprites, simple media, Managed DirectX and Direct3D. Call 972-860-4176 for additional information.
class.alt-description: COSC 1430-2501 is an introductory course to C# and an intensive introduction to the concepts of 2d game programming, including 2d animation, blitting, sprites, simple media, Managed DirectX and Direct3D. Call 972-860-4176 for additional information.

class.title: Prog Fund 1 - Struct C++
class.description: COSC 1436-2001 introduces the concepts of structured programming and is recommended for those students with no prior experience in programming.
class.alt-description: COSC 1436-2001 introduces the concepts of structured programming and is recommended for those students with no prior experience in programming.

class.title: Prog Fund 1 - Struct C++
class.description: COSC 1436-2502 introduces the concepts of structured programming and is recommended for those students with no prior experience in programming.
class.alt-description: COSC 1436-2502 introduces the concepts of structured programming and is recommended for those students with no prior experience in programming.

class.title: Prog Fund 2 - Intro Java
class.description: COSC 1437-2002 is an introduction to computer science and object oriented programming using the java programming language. COSC 1436 or instructor approval is required for COSC 1437. Call 972-860-4176 for approval or additional information.
class.alt-description: COSC 1437-2002 is an introduction to computer science and object oriented programming using the java programming language. COSC 1436 or instructor approval is required for COSC 1437. Call 972-860-4176 for approval or additional information.

class.title: Game Prog 2 - C++
class.description: COSC 2415-2502 is an advanced game programming course teaching the basic concepts of 3d game programming in DirectX using C++. It is intended for those students who have taken Game Prog I. Topics include matrices, vectors, rotations, projections, translations, textures, particles and game physics.
class.alt-description: COSC 2415-2502 is an advanced game programming course teaching the basic concepts of 3d game programming in DirectX using C++. It is intended for those students who have taken Game Prog I. Topics include matrices, vectors, rotations, projections, translations, textures, particles and game physics.

class.title: Prog Fund 3 - Adv Java
class.description: COSC 2436-2501 is an advanced course in computer science and object oriented programming course using the Java programming language. COSC 1437 or instructors approval is required for COSC 2436. Call 972-860-4176 for approval or additional information.
class.alt-description: COSC 2436-2501 is an advanced course in computer science and object oriented programming course using the Java programming language. COSC 1437 or instructors approval is required for COSC 2436. Call 972-860-4176 for approval or additional information.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: Mexico: A Cultural Perspective. This theme-driven, multicultural interdisciplinary course will focus on comparisons between the USA trading partner and neighbor to the south. Movies! Food! No textbook! No tests! Lectures on Maya, Aztecs, Spainards, astronomy, race, class and gender, artists, musicians, Chicano writers, photography, business culture.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: The topic for this course is Aspects of Middle Eastern Cultures.

class.title: Cultural Studies
class.description: New Technologies and Human Behavior examines the cross-cultural influence of new technologies, their impact on the arts, and the influence of the media and advertising on human behavior. This class meets once per week and combines online instruction with classroom activities. Basic Internet skills are required.

class.title: Directed Studies
class.description: DIRS 9170 is a six-week course designed to give students the background to successfully complete SCIT 1407, Anatomy and Physiology. Students who should take this course include those with limited backgrounds in biology or chemistry, who have been out of school for an extended period of time, or who desire an overview of anatomy and physiology.

class.title: College Learning-Reading
class.description: You and your instructor will meet in 30-minute conferences once a week to discuss and evaluate your reading and/or study skills. class.title: College Learning-Writing
class.description: The instructor will meet with students in 30- minute conferences once a week to discuss and evaluate writing skills. Practice and instruction are provided for writing skills as well as for other academic and career programs. During the first week of school all DWRI 0100 students must either come to Room J122 or call 972-860-4782 to make their first appointment.

class.title: Composition II
class.description: Civil Disobedience: This course will examine literature concerning civil disobedience and nonviolent movements in the 20th century. Readings, lectures, films, guest speakers and presentations will help students gain a deeper understanding of the need for non-violence in their daily lives.

class.title: World Lit
class.description: The Hero's Journey: This course examines the trials and tribulations on the hero's journey toward enlightenment. Through this exploration, students will examine their own personal journeys and relate them to the collective human experience.
class.alt-description: The Hero's Journey: This course examines the trials and tribulations on the hero's journey toward enlightenment. Through this exploration, students will examine their own personal journeys and relate them to the collective human experience.

class.title: World Lit
class.description: The Holocaust and other Genocides: By focusing on the literature of the Holocaust (1939-1945) as well as historical readings and lectures, this course will show how people can be led to believe in the necessity of destroying their fellow human beings and the disasters which result. This course will include a visit to the Dallas Memorial Center for Holocaust Studies and lectures from survivors and liberators of the concentration camps.
class.alt-description: The Holocaust and other Genocides: By focusing on the literature of the Holocaust (1939-1945) as well as historical readings and lectures, thi course will show how people can be led to believ in the necessity of destroying their fellow huma beings and the disasters which result. This course will include a visit to the Dallas Memorial Center for Holocaust Studies and lectures from survivors and liberators of the concentration camps.

class.title: Earth Science
class.description: GEOL 1401,1403, and 1404 are 4 credit-hour core lab sciences. GEOL 1405 is a 4 credit-lab hours science which will transfer to most other institutions but may not be used to fulfill requirements for a BHC Associates' degree. Check your degree plan at your transfer institution. Most GEOL courses have an optional camping field trip. The Spring, 2007 trip will be to Central Texas February 23-25 and will cost approximately $95 per person.

class.title: Earth Science II
class.description: This class to run concurrently with GEOL-1405- 2001/400611. Lab will meet the first Saturday of each month (February, March, April, May).
class.alt-description: Lab will meet the first Saturday of each month (February, March, April, May). Prerequisite: either GEOL-1401 or GEOL-1403.

class.title: Hist Geology
class.description: GEOL 1403 is recommended, but not required before GEOL 1404.

class.title: Hist Geology
class.description: Field trip is scheduled for April 15, 2007.
class.alt-description: Field Trip: April 15, 2007

class.title: Environmental Geology
class.description: GEOL 1405 is a course with once-a-month field activities in addition to class discussions. There are no tests in GEOL 1405; grades are based on the degree and quality of participation. Lab will meet the first Saturday of each month (February, March, April and May).

class.title: American Government
class.description: This course is designed for senior adults to share their knowledge and opinion concerning the presidency, foreign policy and national security, legislative process, domestic and economic issues , judicial procedures, civil rights and liberties .

class.title: Mexican-American Politics
class.description: The course covers the influence of Mexican Americans on U.S. government & policies. Special attention will be given to participation in local , state and national politics. Emphasis will be on the Southwest and Texas, Mexican-American cultural ascendancy on the nation, impact on immi grants, and immigration policy in relation to U.S labor market, evaluation of failures/successes of Mexican-American empowerment strategies. Students may sign up for GOVT 2371 or 2311, but not both.

class.title: Learning Framework
class.description: HDEV 1300 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to: motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, test taking skills, reading/writing techniques, note taking, and the development of critical thinking skills. Students may receive credit for PSYC 1300 or HDEV 1300, but not for both.

Students may receive credit for PSYC 1300 or HDEV 1300, but not for both.

class.title: Web Page Design I
class.description: IMED 1316-2001 will focus on designing for the Internet, basic HTML, XHTML, creating and preparing graphics for use on web pages. Dreamweaver will be introduced. On-campus sections are taught in a Macintosh computer lab. Questions? call Lauri Collins at 972-860-4308 or e-mail at lCollins@dcccd.edu.

class.title: Web Page Design I
class.description: IMED 1316-2426 The orientation for this class is online. Login to the class and follow directions in the announcement. The focus will be on designing for the Internet FTP basic HTML, and CSS, as well as preparing graphics for use on web pages. Requires access to the Internet using a current browser (not AOL), e-mail, Dreamweaver and Photoshop software for your particular operating systems. Questions? Call Lauri Collins at 972-860-4308, e-mail lCollins@dcccd.edu or visit the telecollege Web site at http://telecollege.dcccd.edu.

class.title: Game Prog 2 - C++
class.description: ITSE 2431-2502 is an advanced game programming course teaching the basic concepts of 3d game programming in DirectX using C++. class.title: Music Literature
class.description: For more information, please call Octavio Gutierrez at 972-860-4720. Orientation is Jan. 17 at noon, Room D207. If the institution to which the student wishes to transfer requires only one music literature course, the student should take MUSI 1308. If it requires two literature courses, the student should take MUSI 1308 and MUSI 1309. In the latter case, MUSI 1308 meets the Humanities/Visual and Performing Arts requirement.

class.title: Prin of Nutrit
class.description: In addition to learning how the body handles nutrients, students analyze personal eating habits; develop a personal weight control plan; analyze food labels; distinguish between nutrition fact and myth; identify relationships between nutrition and disease; and integrate nutrition information into daily lives. All sections have an Internet component; students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.
class.alt-description: In addition to learning how the body handles nutrients, students analyze personal eating habits; develop a personal weight control plan; analyze food labels; distinguish between nutrition fact and myth; identify relationships between nutrition and disease; and integrate nutrition information into daily lives. All sections have an Internet component; students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.

class.title: Prin of Nutrit
class.description: This section has the same course description as Sections 2001 and 2003 with the following exception: it has a modified Tuesday/ Thursday class meeting schedule. Some class meetings will be traditional and others will be assigned group activities and/or Internet activities. Details will be discussed at first class meeting. Students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.

Students must have Internet access and an e-mail address.

class.title: Prin of Nutrit
class.description: This multimedia course is completed entirely off campus. Students must have Internet access, a CD-ROM drive and a DCCCD student NetMail account. To complete the MANDATORY online orientation, go to http://ecampus.dcccd.edu and follow login procedures. Orientation deadline is Jan. 21. E-mail mManess@dcccd.edu with any questions.

class.title: Prin of Nutrit
class.description: This telecourse has four on-campus exams. MANDATORY orientation at Brookhaven is either Jan. 16, 7-8 p.m., in Room A201 or Jan. 17, 9-10 a.m., in Room A203. If you cannot attend one of these, go to http://telecollege.dcccd.edu/courses/orientations for nutrition orientations on other campuses. Students must have Internet access and an e-mail address. Students, do not buy used telecourse guides.

class.title: Beginning Tai Chi Chuan
class.description: This course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form characterized by low, non-impact movements designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.
class.alt-description: This course is an internal or soft Chinese martial art form characterized by low, non-impact movements designed to build strength and balance and to reduce stress.

class.title: Beginning Yoga/Pilates
class.description: This combination course is designed for beginning and intermediate students. It will utilize low-impact aerobic warm-ups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as equalize muscle strength throughout the body. The focus will be on breathing and relaxation.
class.alt-description: This combination course is designed for beginning and intermediate students. It will utilize low-impact aerobic warm-ups, poses and calisthenics to improve flexibility, balance and posture as well as equalize muscle strength throughout the body. The focus will be on breathing and relaxation.

class.title: Beg Cond Exercise
class.description: This beginning conditioning course designed for students 50 and older will incorporate a variety of exercises to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength, endurance and flexibility. Cardiovascular walking and rhythmic activities and weight training using small free weights and tubing are also included. Accommodation will be made for different levels of fitness.

class.description: This course is designed for students 50 and older and offers activities to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, agility and balance. class.title: Inter Golf
class.description: This class will meet on campus and at the North Texas Golf Center, 2101 Walnut Hill Lane. Basic skills should be developed prior to enrolling in this course. Each class will include driving range practice or actual play. First class meeting is on campus. Equipment is provided. A range and course cost of $50 for the semester payable to the North Texas Golf Center will be due on the first class meeting at the range.

class.description: This course offers varied activities for cardio conditioning beyond the beginner level such as high/low impact, step and circuit training.

class.title: Intermediate Aerobics
class.description: The intermediate aerobics course is designed for students 50 and older and offers activities to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, agility and balance. It includes low-impact aerobics, circuits and walking and will incorporate small hand weights and resistance tubing. Accommodation will be made for various levels of fitness.

class.title: Fund Astronomy
class.description: Orientation for PHYS 1411-2426 online astronomy will be Jan. 18, from 6-7 p.m. in Room K251, Brookhaven College. Lectures, labs and tests are online. Some outdoor observations are required. PHYS 1411 is a Core Curriculum course for non- science majors and includes the study of planetary astronomy.

class.title: Buying/Selling/Internet
class.description: POFI 1104-2200 is a six-session course that will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. You will learn how to write an effective ad and format ad photos and become acquainted with feed- back and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Beginning Internet.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2200 Buying/Selling Internet is a six-session course that will include registration procedures, safe buying practices, evaluating site security, liability and fraud, bidding on auctions and eBay. You will learn how to write an effective ad and format ad photos and become acquainted with feedback and rating, listing tools and different payments systems. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Beginning Internet.

class.title: Computer Secrets
class.description: POFI 1104-2202 will introduce computer shortcuts and tricks of the trade, sometimes referred to as the lesser documented processes used to operate and control Microsoft Windows. This six-session interactive course will include file and folder management, normal and advanced back-up, CD/DVD management, USB control and trouble shooting. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows XP
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2202 Computer Secrets will introduce computer shortcuts and tricks of the trade, sometimes referred to as the lesser documented processes used to operate and control Microsoft Windows. This course will include file and folder management, back-up, CD/DVD management, USB control and trouble shooting. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows XP

class.title: Data Security
class.description: POFI 1104-2203 covers how to protect your personal computer from viruses, "phishing", hacker penetrations, "spoofing", hidden spyware and e-mail identity theft schemes. In this six-session course you will learn techniques to protect data stored on your stored on your computer, how to manage your passwords and reduce the amount of unwanted e-mail. You also will learn how to download and install free programs to protect yourself and your computer. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Computers/Windows
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2203 Data Security covers how to protect your personal computer from viruses, "phishing", hacker penetrations, spoofing, hidden spyware and e-mail identity theft schemes. In this six-session learn techniques to protect data stored on your computer, how to manage your passwords and reduce the amount of unwanted e-mail. You will also learn how to download and install free programs to protect yourself and your computer. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Computers/Windows

class.title: Computer Literacy/Basic Skills
class.description: POFI 1104 is designed for the novice who has little or no experience with computers. In this one week, five session course, you will practice using the mouse, learn about the components of the computer, including the keyboard and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing Basic Computer you will be ready to enroll in Windows XP.

In this one-week, five-session course, you will practice using the mouse, learn about the components of the computer, including the keyboard and perform rudimentary tasks. After completing Basic Computer you will be ready to enroll in Windows XP.

class.title: Blog With Family and Friends
class.description: POFI 1104 is a six-session course that will introduce you to an easy-to -use Web site where you can quickly post thoughts, interact with family and friends, and more. It's free, easy to do, non-technical and requires no programming. You and your family can post photos for the family to see. Your blog can be restricted to your family or friends only, or open to the world. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Beginning Internet.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2207 Blog With Family And Friends is a six-session course that will introduce you to an easy-to-use Web site where you can post thoughts, interact with family and friends and more. It's free, easy to do, non-technical and requires no programming. You and your family can post photos for the family to see. Your blog can be restricted to your family or friends only, or open to the world. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Beginning Internet.

class.title: Access 2003/Card Files
class.description: POFI 1104-2208 will facilitate the creation of personal card files. In this six-session course you will use Access 2003 to create files such as addresses, photos, household inventory, recipes, etc. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.description: POFI 1104 is a six-session course that will introduce you to an easy-to -use Web site where you can quickly post thoughts, interact with family and friends, and more. class.title: Genealogy II
class.description: POFI 1104-2210 builds on the research process and methodology of Genealogy Part I. Topics include research strategies, problems analysis , published sources, immigration, emigration, naturalization and records, American migration, writing lineage societies and Internet search sites. This five-session course will include a working trip to the Genealogy Research Center of the Dallas Public Library. Familiarity with a computer is helpful but not required. Recommended Prerequisite: Genealogy I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2210 Genealogy II builds on the research process and methodology of Genealogy Part I. Topics include research strategies, problems analysis published sources, immigration, emigration, naturalization and records, American migration, writing lineage societies and Internet search sites. This five-session course will include a working trip to the Genealogy Research Center of the Dallas Public Library. Familiarity with a computer is helpful but not required. Recommended Prerequisite: Genealogy I

class.title: Computer Health
class.description: POFI 1104-2211 will focus on a series of topics designed to keep the Windows Operating System running smoothly and efficiently. A second general area will address the aging computer and its performance. During this six-session course, you will learn about hardware that can be added to your older computer, the cost, and how to determine when to buy a new computer. Guidelines to consider when purchasing a new computer also will be covered. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2211 Computer Health will focus on a series of topics designed to keep the Windows Operating System running smoothly and efficiently.A second general area will address the aging computer and its performance. During this six-session course, you will learn about hardware that can be added to your older computer, the cost and how to determine when to buy a new computer. Guidelines to consider when purchasing a new computer also will be covered. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Genelogy on the Internet
class.description: POFI 1104-2212 will give you hands-on computer sessions focusing on techniques for using search engines, accessing sites with indexes and discovering links to genealogical sites. Other activities in this four- session course will include finding and saving maps and images, using the U.S. GenWeb resources and participating in a fun and challenging Genealogical Scavenger Hunt! This course will sharpen your skills in finding new and unusual sources of genealogical information. Recommend- ed Prerequisites: Intro to Windows, Beginning Internet and Genealogy Part I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2212 Genealogy on the Internet will give you hands-on computer sessions focusing on techniques for using search engines, accessing sites with indexes and discovering links to genealogical sites. Other activities in this four-session course will include will include finding and saving maps and images, using the U.S. GenWeb resources and participating in a fun and challenging Genealogical Scavenger Hunt! This course will sharpen your skills in finding new and unusual sources of genealogical information. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Windows, Beginning Internet and Genealogy Part I

class.title: Excel 2003/PART I
class.description: POFI 1104-2213 will develop skills in the basics of Microsoft Excel, a program for spreadsheet and arithmetic functions. This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, short- cuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2213 Excel 2003 Part I will develop skills in the basics of Microsoft Excel, a program for spreadsheet and arithmetic functions. This six-session course will include creating and editing spreadsheets, naming, saving and printing spreadsheets; navigating within worksheets; menus, shortcuts and toolbars for formatting spreadsheets and writing basic formulas. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Income Tax
class.description: POFI 1104-2214 is a tax preparation course using H and R Block TaxCut software to prepare a typical Form 1040 Federal Income Tax return. This four-session course will include Social Security benefits, mutual fund distributions, interest and dividend income, IRA distributions, capital gains, pension income and 2007 estimated taxes. Students will be required to purchase the TaxCut software.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2214 Income Tax is a tax preparation course using H and R Block TaxCut software to prepare a typical Form 1040 Federal Income Tax return. This four-session course will include Social Security benefits, mutual fund distributions, interest and dividend income, IRA distributions, capital gains, pension income and 2007 capital gains, pension income and 2007 estimated taxes. Students will be required to purchase the TaxCut software.

class.title: Greeting Cards
class.description: POFI 1104-2215 will use Hallmark Studio software to produce greeting cards, scrapbook pages and other projects. In this six-session course, students will learn how to add sound, music and photos to greeting cards sent by e-mail. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2215 Greeting Cards will use Hallmark Studio software to produce greeting cards, scrapbook pages and other projects. cards, scrapbook pages and other projects. In this six-session course, students will learn how to add sound, music and photos to greeting cards sent by e-mail. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Internet I
class.description: POFI 1104 will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL, and other browsers. These five or six-session courses will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and discussion groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows
class.alt-description: POFI 1104 Internet Part I will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL and other browsers. These five or six-session courses will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and discussion groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: POFI 1104-2218 will cover the various features of a digital camera. In this six-session course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2218 Digital Cameras will cover the various features of a a digital camera. In this six-session course, students will learn about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed.

class.title: Legacy Family Tree Part III
class.description: POFI 1104-2219 will concentrate on functions in the Legacy Edition. Topics in this four-session course may include how to store images of photographs and documents, image formats, colors and assigning pictures to individuals, events and sources using the Picture Center, using the U.S. County verifier; importing and learning to use the GeoDatabase and specialized reports such as ToDo and Chronology reports. Recommended Prerequisite: Legacy Family Tree, Part II
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2219 Legacy Family Tree Part III will concentrate on functions in the Legacy Deluxe Edition. Topics in this four-session course may include how to store images of photographs and documents, image formats, colors and assigning pictures to individuals, events and sources using the Picture Center, using the U.S. County verifier; importing and learning to use the GeoDatabase and specialized reports such as ToDo and Chronology reports. Recommended Prerequisite: Legacy Legacy Family Tree, Part II

class.title: PowerPoint
class.description: POFI 1104-2220 is a presentation program that can be used with digital photos, text, clip art and objects. This software enables you to create presentations of memorable events, such as birthdays, anniversaries, weddings or vacations. It also can be used to create life stories of family members or yourself. In this six-session course you will also learn how to enhance basic presentations using custom animation, transition effects, drawing objects, 3D effects and re-coloring. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Windows and Beginning Word
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2220 PowerPoint is a presentation program that can be used with digital photos, text, clip art and objects. This software enables you to create presentations of memorable events, such as birthdays, anniversaries, weddings or vacations. It also can be used to create life stories of family members or yourself. In this six-session course you will also learn how to enhance basic presentations using custom animation, transition effects, drawing objects, 3D effects and re-coloring. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Windows and Beginning Word

class.title: Photoshop Elements I
class.description: POFI 1104-2221 will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this six-session course, you also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Internet Part I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2221 Photoshop Elements I will help you import, organize and enhance your photos. In this six-session course, you also will develop skills in cropping, rotating, resizing, straightening and red eye removal. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Internet Part I

class.title: Photoshop Elements II
class.description: POFI 1104 Photoshop Elements Part II will build on skills from Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as dust and spot removal. In this six-session course you also will use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Required Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104 Photoshop Elements Part II will build on skills from Part I and cover how to correct color and exposure as well as dust and spot removal. In this six-session course you also will use the clone tool to repair damage and remove unwanted parts of the photo. Required Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements I

class.title: Photoshop Elements III
class.description: POFI 1104-2223 will build on skills from Part II. Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of photos and how to work with various types of layers, including text layers. In this six-session course, you also will experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Required Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements II
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2223 Photoshop Elements III will build on skills from Part II Students will work on a project as well as learn different ways of creating masks to isolate specific areas of photos and how to work with various types of layers, including text layers. In this six-session course, you also will experiment with blend modes and plug-in filters. Required Prerequisite: Photoshop Elements II

class.title: Users/Problem Solving
class.description: POFI 1104-2224 meets four times during the semester. Each session of this course will have a guest speaker, special program and/or demonstrations to increase your knowledge of computers and the Internet In addition, students will have an opportunity to ask questions about various computer and software problems they have encountered. This course meets on Fridays, Feb. 2, March 2, April 13 and May 4.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2224 Users Group/Problem Solving meets four times during the Each session of this course will have a guest speaker, special program and/or demonstrations to increase your knowledge of computers and the Internet. In addition, students will have an opportunity to ask questions about various computer and software problems they have encountered. This course meets on Fridays, Feb. 2, March 2, April 13 and May 4.

class.title: Word 2003 I
class.description: POFI 1104-2225 will emphasize the basics of Microsoft's word processing program. This six session course includes creating and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts; formatting, cutting, copying and pasting text; margins and indents; and inserting graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2225 Word 2003/Part I will emphasize the basics of Micro- soft's word processing program. This six-session course includes creat- ing and editing Word documents; naming, saving and printing documents; menus, toolbars and shortcuts; formatting, cutting, copying and pasting text; margins and indents; and inserting graphics and text from other documents and applications. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Internet II
class.description: POFI 1104-2226 will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. In this six- session course students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended Prerequisites: Intro to Windows and Internet/Part I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2226 Internet Part II will cover advanced e-mail functions, advanced searches and quick searches and shortcuts to addressing Web sites. In this six-session course students will learn how to download programs (such as games and Adobe Acrobat Reader), manage pop-ups, spam mail, cookies and avoid viruses. How to personalize the Internet experience and use calendars will also be explained. Recommended prerequisites: Intro to Windows and Internet/Part I

class.title: Publisher
class.description: POFI 1104-2227 will introduce the design of a variety of publications, such as greeting cards, invitations, fliers, newsletters, postcards, calendars, business cards and signs. This six-session course also will cover predefined layouts that may be used to simplify formatting your publication if you do not design your own layout.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2227 Publisher will introduce the design of a variety of publications, such as greeting cards, invitations, fliers, newsletters, postcards, calendars, business cards and signs. This six-session course This six-session course also will cover predefined layouts that may be used to simplify formatting your publication if you do not design your own layout.

class.title: Word 2003 Part II
class.description: POFI 1104-2228 builds on the concepts learned in Word Part I to work with columns, paragraph numbering, graphics, section breaks and creating envelopes and labels. This six-session course will include how to merge a database of names and addresses into a standard "boilerpoint" for mail merge as well as how to change Word's default settings and refine your knowledge of advanced table techniques. Recommonded prerequisite: Word, Part I
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2228 Word 2003/Part II builds on the concepts learned in Word Part I to work with columns, paragraph numbering, graphics, section breaks and creating envelopes and labels. This six-session course will include how to merge a database of names and addresses into a standard "boilerpoint" for mail merge, as well as how to change Word's default settings and refine your knowledge of advanced table techniques Recommonded prerequisite: Word, Part I

class.title: Writing/Remembering
class.description: POFI 1104-2229 is a five-session course that begins with writing your life story, progresses to incorporating your story into your family's genealogy, and concludes with how to compile an interesting family history. Topics are discussed that start you thinking about your life, what you want to record for your family, how to put your genealogical information into a publishable format, and more. Class time is divided between lectures and writing. A workable knowledge of Microsoft Word is required. Use of PowerPoint is explored.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2229 Writing and Remembering: Personal Stories & Family His- History is a five-session course that begins with writing your life story, progresses to incorporating your story into your family's genealogy, and concludes with how to compile an interesting family history. Topics are discussed that start you thinking about your life, what you want to record for your family, how to put your genealogical information into a publishable format, and more. Class time is divided between lectures and writing. A workable knowledge of Microsoft Word is required. Use of PowerPoint is explored.

class.title: Wildflower Identification
class.description: POFI 1104-2230 will help you identify wildflowers that are indigenous to North Texas. Focus will be on identification by plant families through Internet research of wildflower websites. Basic Internet skills are necessary. Students will have an opportunity to practice their identification skills. All materials will be furnished.
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2230 Wildflower Identification will help you identify wildflowers that are indigenous to North Texas. Focus will be on identification by plant families through internet research of Web sites. Basic Internet skills are necessary. Students will have an opportunity to practice their identification skills. All materials will be furnished.

class.title: Customizing Windows XP
class.description: POFI 1104-2231 will help you brush up on Windows and add new tricks. In this six-session course you will learn to adjust the mouse, super size icons, change fonts, move and size the task bar. You can brighten up computer screen by selecting colors, wallpaper and screen savers. Other topics include screen capture, setting the type of folders, auto start programs, define special characters and more. Recommended Prerequistie: Windows XP
class.alt-description: POFI 1104-2231 Customizing Windows XP will help you brush up on Windows and add new tricks. In this six-session course you will learn to adjust the mouse, super size icons, change fonts, move and size the task bar. You can brighten up your computer screen by selecting colors, wallpaper and screen savers. Other topics include screen capture, setting the type of folders, auto start programs, defininge special characters and more. Recommended Prerequisite: Windows XP

class.title: Internet I
class.description: POFI 1104-2250 will use Microsoft Internet Explorer with reference to SBC/Yahoo, AOL, and other browsers. These five or six-session courses will emphasize all basic e-mail functions plus attachments, searches using Google and other search engines, addressing Web pages, using instant messenger and discussion groups. You will learn how to shop and purchase online and other activities at popular Web sites. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows

class.title: Digital Cameras
class.description: POFI 1104-2 will give an overview of the various features of a digital camera. In this five-session course, students will lean about the process of transferring photos to the computer, how to take pictures with an eye for computer enhancement and for use in e-mails and Web pages. Storage and retrieval of digital photos will be reviewed.

class.title: Web Page Design I
class.description: POFI 1104-2254 will focus on designing a simple personal or business Web site and covers how to put photos online and create e-mail links. In this five-session course, students will learn about free or inexpensive Web site hosting for their personal site. No prior knowledge of Web design is required. Students must be able to all all classes. Recommended prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Internet, Part I

class.title: Blog With Family/Friends
class.description: POFI 1104 is a five-session course that will introduce you to an easy- to-use Web site where you can quickly post thoughts, interact with family and friends, and more. It's free, easy to do, non-technical and requires no programming. You and your family can post photos for the family to see. Your blog can be restricted to your family or friends only, or open to the world. Recommended Prerequisite: Intro to Windows and Beginning Internet.

class.title: Learning Frameworks
class.description: PSYC 1300 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to: motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, test taking skills, reading/writing techniques, note taking, and the development of critical thinking skills. Students may receive credit for PSYC 1300 or HDEV 1300, but not for both.

class.title: Learning Frameworks
class.description: PSYC 1300 will help students develop skills that will support their success in college. Topics include, but are not limited to: motivation and self-discipline, time management, effective communication, understanding the psychology of the classroom, test taking skills, reading/writing techniques, note taking, and the development of critical thinking skills. Students may receive credit for PSYC 1300 or HDEV 1300, but not for both.

course.title: Spc Tpcs in Spanish Lang/Liter
course.long-title: Special Topics in Spanish Language and Literature

class.title: Beginning Spanish Language
class.description: In this 10-week course you will build a beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
class.alt-description: In this 10-week course you will build a beginning vocabulary, basic grammar and pronunciation skills. Comprehension will increase as you participate in listening and speaking exercises with classmates and the instructor. Instructional materials will be used as a way to increase skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.

class.title: Interm. Spanish Language
class.description: Recommended Prerequisite: Beginning Spanish or permission of instructor. This 10-week course is a continuation of Beginning Spanish and seeks to develop additional vocabulary and speaking skills. You will continue oral practice, as well as the reading, writing, and grammar skills necessary to enhance your communication and comprehension skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
class.alt-description: Recommended Prerequisite: Beginning Spanish or permission of instructor. This 10-week course is a continuation of Beginning Spanish and seeks to develop additional vocabulary and speaking skills. You will continue oral practice, as well as the reading, writing, and grammar skills necessary to enhance your communication and comprehension skills. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.

class.title: Spec. Topics Spanish Language
class.description: RECOMMENDED PREREQUISITE: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor. This 10-week course will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
class.alt-description: RECOMMENDED PREREQUISITE: Intermediate Spanish or permission of instructor. This 10-week course will include a grammar and vocabulary review, a survey of literature, current topics, cultural videos and discussion. New topics will be introduced each semester. Additional work may be done on a self-paced basis outside of class.
